transcript.content: Happy Christmas, Ricky.
Happy Christmas, Steve.
Who invited Yoko?
John Lennon, “Happy Xmas (War Is Over)”.
John Lennon, and Yoko Ono, “Happy Christmas, War is Over” on Radio 2. I'm Ricky Gervais with me, Steve Merchant.
Uhh, Good morning
…and our producer
Karl Pilkington, but more about Karl later, we’ll have to - we want introduce the world to Karl, don't we?
It's extraordinary to think that they’re people yet they have not experienced Karl.
I know.
A whole new audience is gonna discover -
I think of me and Stephen as like, Anthony Hopkins in “The Elephant Man”.
Yeah
Just taking Karl round the country - the World.
Yeah
Maybe just letting - maybe some doctors and surgeons might want to, uh, after today certainly -
We just drop a sheet, he’s there, nude, and they can just ask him questions, examine him, see what makes him tick.
You know uhh, that is Karl's favorite film, by the way, “The Elephant Man”. He said - he loves it.
He said, “One”, he said, “the title tells you exactly what you're going to get.”
Yeah.

He loved that, right? He said, “Two, it's sad”. And I was saying, “Why is it sad?” He said, “Well there’s that bit where they take him to show all the surgeons. And the Elephant Man is all naked and that, and the bloke goes, “the genitals are normal”. And Karl went, “Think of that. The one thing you would want like an elephant, and he gets the head.” That's why he thought it was sad.
Steve Laughs
That’s the kind of mind process of Karl, which we’ll introduce to you later, in the meantime -
Well, yeah, you know, if you're expecting Jonathan Ross, then you’re gutted.
Yeah
You probably know me from such works as; The Office, Extras, Alias.
Yeah.

Karl uhh, you don't know about, Steven is, is more familiar. Stephen co-wrote and directed “The Office” and “Extras” with me, um. You may have seen him in “Extras” as the agent, uh, you may have seen him briefly in “The Office”. He is - a goggle-eyed freak.
You’re referring to the character there, are you, or?
Yeah, whatever.
Thanks, great.
We’ll
It's just a little -
I'm just trying to paint a picture for people, at Christmas.
Sure.
Steve
Yeah. I wouldn’t say goggle-eyed, I think google-eyed freaks harsh, you know, these are pretty - these are designer specs. And yeah, I admittedly, I'm, I’m a little bit tall but uhh-
Six foot seven.
Yeah, but let’s not have a go at that.
Karl, we've got more like this later, I think we should play a record. We've done introductions -
Yeah, pop a little song on
But do you remember - the first time you saw Steve?
Well, let's, let's pop a little song ‘a that, right? Chat about it in a bit.
Alright
Alright
Bruce Springsteen

transcript.content: Bruce Springsteen, “Santa Claus is Coming to Town”
Bruce Springsteen, Santa Claus is Coming to Town. Merry Christmas everyone.
Yeah, Merry Christmas indeed.
I'm Ricky Gervais, with me, Steve Merchant.
Hello.

And uh, Karl Pilkington. If you have tuned in to hear Jonathan, it's the last time I’ll mention him, we haven't got him today. You've got us for the next couple of Saturdays. I feel like a step-father.
Sure
You know what I mean? I want to say to the listener. “You know, I’ll never replace Daddy.”
Yeah
“But I am here and I, and I’ll do my best for you and I love you.”
Yeah
On the other hand I want to go, “Listen, I'm doing mummy now. Live with it.”
Steve Laughs
Yeah, yeah. No, that's, that's exactly right. Yeah. And hopefully that people will appreciate us and enjoy us just as much as Jonathan.
I don't care if they don't.
Really?
In fact, I intend to shave millions of listeners off this by the end of the 2 hours -
You’re doing a good job
But, the ones that have stayed listening to the end, they’ll love it.
Yeah. Both of them.
Yeah. Yeah.
And I think I've got to go have Christmas dinner with them tomorrow anyway, so, I could just have a chat -
So we're introducing ourselves. I’m Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington

Um, now it's difficult to describe Karl, I just think you'll have to get to know him over the next um, two hours. But um, we have, um, taken the liberty of getting some stuff ready for you if you wanna find out more about him, if you go to rickygervais.com, we've put up a special little page, go into "Who's Karl?" and we've put a little biography up of him and loads of pictures and you have never seen a head rounder. He looks like Mr Spoon from Button Moon.
Yes.
Do you know what I mean? Or.. Bod, grown up. There's a little bit of Charlie Brown in there, he's even got a little striped shirt.
His perfectly round head; it's balding like to... and it's not - it's not - a sort of like; a, a good balding. It's sort of like - he looks like a worn tennis ball.
Yeah.
Do you know what I mean? He's got a little bit of growth...
It's not that sort of Telly Savalas "cool" bald.
No, it's just a scruffy little. I don't know what it is.
Happy Christmas 'n' that.
Ricky laughs
What you think of that then, Karl? Your introduction to the nation.
Well, you know, if we're going to start picking on looks and stuff... Like you mentioned before we can, we can go over everyone in this room.
What?
I mean, let's make it fair.
Ricky laughs
What?
Let's have a chat. Let's have a chat about.. about Steve over there.
What? What are you talking about?
Well, you know, you know how.. sort of how I felt when I first saw you.
Ricky laughs
What!? What do you - wait wait wait! Right, don't go mad Steve. Let Karl speak, right? This is his platform.
No, no. I'm just saying - you just said about painting a picture?
Yeah, go then!
I wouldn't paint a picture of that.
Ricky explodes into laughter
Is - is.. is what - no I'm not - Steve, you know I'm not having a go, mate. You're a good - you're...
What? Of course - what do you mean you're not "having a go" - it sounds like you're having a go!
Wh-what did you think when you first saw him, when he - when he first walked into that room? All those years ago?
Uh... Sort of.. Thought he looked like a cartoon.
Ricky explodes into laughter
No, no, Steve! Admit.. you know - but you know, that you look a little bit odd. This isn't like a..
What!?
..this - this isn't like a shock to ya'.
Ricky continues laughing
You've had this - how old are you now?
Thirty-one. But I...
So you're thirty - like, thirty-one... Uh, what did you look like as a baby?
Ricky laughs
I mean...
Why is this a character assessment it's - it's Christmas Eve?
No no no - I'm not having a go, I'm just saying what it was like. Now I'm - now I'm used to you now, when I see you I don't sort of double take anymore.
Ricky laughs
I just...
He's coming out with this!
No, but you know, wh-when you popped in 'n that it was just a bit of a shock and now, you know, I-I've got used to it 'n that.
Good. You're happy now? You can cope now?
Hold on! You were shocked when you saw Steve Merchant? You told me you once you went to school with two fellas who had big heads and webbed hands and feet.
Yeah?
And they weren't related! Why - why were there two people like that at your school and yet you find Steve... freaky?
He never said freaky.
Ricky bursts into laughter
You said freaky.
Play a record!
You said freaky.
Madonna - Hung Up
Madonna. Hung up. Now, she's um.. given us, uh... a platinum disc to give away.
Nice!
We were - and we got - big prizes from Madonna and uh...
If people are rushing around today on Christmas Eve, thinking "I've wanted to buy a Madonna platinum disc for uh, for me mum! There's no ch -- I can't find one anywhere in Boots!"
We'll give you things you can't buy in the shops!
Perfect.
Um, and that's coming up. But - Karl, just - I, I, I don't want to - I'm not stirring it, right? You - you started a little bit of a war with Steve.
Well you are stirring it!
Well, no no no no no no!
This is what - this is stirring right now. This is the terminology.
But! Do you know the - the fellas in your school?
Yeah?
With big heads and webbed feet and webbed hands?
Webbed hands, yeah.
But they hung around together, did they?
Uhh... I don't think they did.
And they were nothing to do with each other?
No. I think people expected them to sort of knock about together. But they must have thought "uh, that would be too obvious".
Steve laughs
You know what I mean?
Ricky laughs
But where did you live? Near a power plant? I mean why- why did you have...
I don't think it had anything to do with that though.
Sometimes you get a little... look at Steve, he didn't live near a power plant.
Listen, can I just stop you there, right? Let me just stop you there, because I.. It always happens as soon as we know.. it's going to be a nice day and suddenly having a go, right?

Now this..this got sent on the email, okay. Now this is not me saying this, this is someone who's forwarded a review that was put on the web. It was a review of your appearance on one of Ricky's stand-up comedy DVDs. Okay I'm reading.. I'm quoting this this is not me saying it. It says that er: "Karl through a combination of is intriguing way of thinking and slightly less than human appearance, right..

Karl may just be the proof needed to muffle the cries of creationists the world over as this missing link demonstrates that not only did man evolve from apes but the process isn't quite finished yet."
Okay, now that's someone else. And external, person's opinion of you.
The... the terrible thing about that is Karl's feelings aren't hurt because he didn't understand a word of that.
I said there were creationist that lost, that lost him.

That lost him.. You've just got to remember that, you know when people say they're talking to their cat and they go "Oh look, look at him looking at us". It's like you can understand what we're saying. Well Karl's got
That look but you know, he can't understand.
Yeah
..what what you're saying. All right, Karl?

No, but all.. I mean now we're now we're talking about your head and that, right? When you go back to say, your mam and dad. It's Christmas time, right? There's a lot of people traveling up and down the country, going back seeing their mam and dad; they probably haven't seen them all year, right? When you go back -- is it a shock to them again?
Laughs
No.. Do you know, like how you get used to how someone... Like I say, I'm used to you. I see you a few times a week -- I don't do the double-take. But what I mean is, when you go back do they sort of
..go, "Oop, here he is." You know what I mean?
Laughs
Play a record, this is.. it's I..
Let's leave it then..
Let's move on, then, because I'm going to get angry and we haven't even got.. it's only.. it's not even 25-past yet!
It's Christmas!
Little bit of Simon and Garfunkel?
Yeah, oh, this is beautiful!
Simon and Garfunkel - April Come She Will
Simon and Garfunkel - April Come She Will. Looking forward to Spring already.
Laughs.
Yeah, it's a bit premature, but fine.
Well, I thought it'd.. you know, be nice.. you know.. it's a bit cold..
Let's get Christmas over first, alright?
Christmas over.. I love that, my mum used to go: "Oh that's Christmas over.."
"..for another year!"
Laughs

You would look forward to it all year. You know -- buy things out of the catalog, pay for it for the next 12 months then go "Oh, that's that over now." Right.. you know 5:00 Christmas Day, that was it.
When is Christmas over?
Its.. hmm... I would say Christmas is over when you've seen the Vicar of Dibley Christmas Special.
Really?
Yeah
See, I think it was earlier than that. I think it was when your.. the elderly ones fall asleep at about 3:30
Really?
Then wake up because the kid's playing with something noisy..
Yeah
A game that goes "Wah wah wah ah ah ah ah ah" or something like that..
That's when Christmas is over.
You, you know what, you're getting this year then?
Exactly. I do. Oh, ah.. oh.. ahh right, I was shopping with Karl. Ahh... don't give anything away that I bought, right? Because it'd go.. right.. you know..

But, I have gotta tell you something, um.. I, uh.. we went to this one shop -- I didn't get anything from it, so I can talk about this -- for, uh.. looking for a present for my girlfriend Jane. And it was a beautiful shop in St James' -- they're all beautiful around there -- and it was this shop of sort of.. iconoclastic..
... sort of, antiquities and it was things that are.. this guy..
You had to ring about for the bell for the bloke to to come down. Karl was just so confused about that, he's used to someone standing there going "Can I help you? What size do you want?" right?
And he came down, and he.. loved his stuff. He absolutely loved his stuff.
And what sort of stuff was it?
It was sort of stuff that he'd erm got from sort of like Churches..
It was tat.
It wasn't tat.
It was old stuff, Steve.

It was carvings, it was the 16th and 17th century -- of saints, right? And I said "this is beautiful" and I was talking to him, and I said "what's this?" and he was going "Oh that's so and so" and I was going "Oh that's wonderful"

Look at that, right? And I overheard Karltrying to make conversation -- he said this guy is so proud of this stuff and it's you know -- 16th century 17th century. He went "what's the newest thing you've got in here?"
Brilliant
And the bloke went: "well, we've got a statue I think from the sixties of Lenin"

He went "Right" he went "when was the last time you got something in?" Bloke went: "we get something in every day". And afterwards, I said: "why were you asking those questions?" He was going: "just it always confused me with antiques, what happens.."
"when they sell that out, they're not making any more."
Laughs
I just thought it was sort of a good business to get into, that's all, you know what I mean?
Why?
There'll always be antiques, Karl.
Well, you said it yourself: the place wasn't buzzing, was it?
Chuckles
Chuckles

He had to pop down -- he couldn't even be bothered, sort of, sat in the shop waiting for a customer because probably days go by where nothing's happening. Doesn't it? For you to ring the bell to wake him up to say "Oh, I want to come look at this old stuff".. forget it, you know what I mean?
So you've got all your Christmas shopping then call you your bang up to date... You don't have to..
Yeah, I've sorted most stuff out -- but here's one for you, right. Here's a little question.
Go on.
I've finished a job. All right, where I've been working somewhere for like, about 10 years.
You can say it:
No, I know.
XFM, the local radio [station] where we met.
It was a good little place to work and everything, but I've had enough.
Yeah.
You know what I mean? After 10 years..
You're moving on; you've gone up in the world. We're on Radio 2.
Yeah it's good.
So you're moving on, yeah?
And so that, so the gave me a present, right? They sort of said to me "what do you want?"
Yeah.
"You've done 10 years, tell us what gift you want, and we'll sort you out."
Yeah.
So, I said "Oh, brilliant, yeah." So, I knew, Suzanne, my girlfriend wanted a camera.
No!
What a... so.. OK?

So, they got me a camera, they wrapped it up and they, you know -- at my leaving do -- and so they said "open it", so I'm going "No, no. I don't want to open it" and they're like "what was going on?" So well "I'm going to give it to Susan for Christmas"
No.
Now why..
That's.. That's a disgrace.
But why is it though?
You can't.. you.. because it's..
It doesn't matter though because I could have had a gift for myself and I didn't.. I decided
You can't.. No, no, no, no, no. That's..
Second-hand
It's not second-hand..
It is second-hand
It's not been used, I haven't even opened it.
But surely the point about buying a gift for your girlfriend is that you've got in the shop and done it -- there's a sentimental attachment.
It's not about that.
It is thought. No, it is about that.
It's not. It's about them getting what they want.
So if you were walking down the street and you saw a camera and it was brand new and you went "Oh, here you are, Suzanne - Happy Christmas!"
Err..
So are you going to tell her it was a gift for your..?
Well, no, she's at work today so she doesn't need to know..
So you're not even going to tell her?
No point.
So you've got deceit, as well as meanness.
Doesn't matter does it? She's got what she wanted.
That's disgraceful.
It's not disgraceful.
Okay, I want to get people on the text: "Do you think that Karl's in the right?" 88291.. 88291 Should Karl be giving a gift to his girlfriend -- which he's passing off...
She's getting it anyway
...as his own present.

Yeah, hold on, wait a minute, right? You cannot -- the thing is, it'd be alright if you were giving it to a mate or something -- but I'd still tell them. I'd say "Look, I didn't pay for this, but I knew you wanted a camera."
Ehhh..
But you're not going to tell her, so she's going to think you've spent £700 or something
It's not even a £700 free camera!
Laughs.
He went: "She'll never think that I spent £700 on her.
That is brilliant. Well it's an improvement on last year. Do you remember what he got her last year?
I'd rather he told us.
Come on, what did you get your partner -- your life partner..
Your lover
..last year for Christmas. How long have you been with her, first?
Erm... 11 years
11 years -- what did you get a last year for Christmas?
Some condoms..
Laughs
I mean, that's unbelievable
Two packets.
Yeah, no. No. You bought her a big bumper packet of condoms from Boots or something. And you..
Got one packet, free.
Yeah? And they've all being used.
Pretenders - 2000 Miles
Aztec Camera - Walk out to Winter
Walk Out To Winter - Aztec Camera. Before that, The Pretenders. It's Ricky Gervais show but I'm here: Steve Merchant. Karl Pilkington's here. Christmas Eve, Radio 2, Merry Christmas.
Producer just came in and said: "oh, can you give out the web address? It's erm bbc.co.uk/radio2" I went: "Yeah, why?" He said "Well, just in case people want to listen to this show again."
Laugh
Yeah, Right.
Laughs
Ohh...
He's got a sense of humor.
Yeah! Yeah, as if. So Karl, we've had loads and loads of emails..

We should just... in case you just tuned in Karl received a leaving gift of a digital camera, when he was leaving a job -- and he's not even unwrapped it -- he's giving it straight to his girlfriend for tomorrow, which I think Ricky and I were trying to express.. [inaudible]
He's not going to tell her it was free, and he thinks there's nothing wrong..
It wasn't free; it was 10 years of my life, I had to do there.
Yeah, and you've been 11 years with her -- think what she's gone through! she's had 11 years of her life.
Right, yep.
Well, yeah, I was gonna.. yeah..
"Karl would have been OK if he'd have kept quiet. Idiot." Dave in Salford
Cheers.
He's right, yeah, he's right.

"It's a disgrace, he has dishonoured his former employer and girlfriend." from Graham in Line [trails off] Thats that's a good point -- it's an insult to the people that worked there there! They got you something, they thought that you'd really like, they really went out and thought about it, they wrapped up -- you didn't even unwrap it in front of... because you couldn't be bothered to wrap it again, even! You could have unwrapped it..
Do you know.. Do you know what I really hope's happened? That before they gave it to you, they took pictures of their genitals in the toilet is a little going away... And so your..
...girlfriend's gonna get that and get loads, and loads, and loads of pictures of offal from people to work Xfm. That would be the best Christmas gift for me.
What if there's a note or something inside that they've all write.. written and signed? "To Karl.."
Look! He's thinking about that. Look, that is the first time he's ever thought about. Look at his head! look at his head!
Kirsty in Hull says: "I think Karl's heart is in the right place. Don't know about his brain, though."
Good point.
A fair point. (Snickers)
There's one [text message] here: "I once got a frozen box of fish my husband found whilst working in the Chip Shop"
"..Karl's girlfriend should be grateful"
Laughs
Yeah, I suppose so. That it.. I mean, it's staggering.
Here's one from Jane, it says: "Better his girlfriend has the camera, as it looks like he hasn't got opposable thumbs."
Snickers
And that's people having to dig; they don't even know you.

But, you know, you know why I'm not, err.. sort of big fan of sort of Christmas and buying presents and that anyway. Because it's.. I had bad experiences in the past, when like, you know, buying buying stuff for people go on, you know, like, when I was a kid and that, right?
Yep
And y'know, you put a lot of thought into buying presents, don't you when you're a kid because you know, you haven't got that much money to spend an' that.
How old are we talking?
Errm... 'bout eight?
Right? Okay.
Yeah.
About eight.
So you look like you did but you had hair I assume?
Yep, right. So eight years old an' that, I'm putting a bit of planning into it thinking 'Oh, you know, what does- what will me mam want?'
Yeah
Now me mam's a big fan of er... gnomes
Ricky snorts
Right...
Obviously
Like gnomes, gnomes and-
She must be pleased how you turned out
Ricky giggles
-and fairies and stuff like that, right? Little elves and all that stuff, right?
Sure.
So I thought, right? I'll look for something that's, that's, a bit gnomish.
Right
You got a Noel Edmonds
Steve laughs
And there was this shop- there was this- there was this- there was this shop sort of down the road that, umm, sort of sold a lot of tat right?
Oh good
Steve giggles
Umm, Sort of- you know one of them shops where everything's quite cheap, it's... sort of they sell things individually, that shouldn't be like, toilet rolls, and...
Ricky laughs
...that sort of thing.
They used to be called 'everything's a pound' but now there's some that are 'everything's 99p'.
Yeah
Because a pound wasn't cheap enough.
They're undercutting the pound shops.
Yeah.
Yeah, go on.

So anyway. So I had a look in there thinking, 'right, let's have a look and see if they've got any gnomes an' that' and the closest thing they 'ad, right? Was uh, this, this figure that's called uh, a Victoria Plum.
Victoria Plum, right.
It's like a little-
Ricky immitates a Manchester accent
No, Victoria Plum, get it right
Right?
It's like little- it's like a- it's like a woman gnome, right?
Okay.

So I thought 'Oh she'll love that, right?' So save that- I think it was about two quid, right? Invest in one of them; take it home, I'm well chuffed in myself an' that; wrapping it up, pop it under the tree thinking I can't wait to see her face light up when she sees this.
Aww
Yeah.
Anyway, you know like when you're a kid- I bought that like two weeks before Christmas.
Sure.
Right. And you know, when you're sort of excited you want to give someone a present earlier, d' y'know what I mean?
Yeah yeah yeah.
Yeah.

I- I- I sort of took me mam into this shop. Aright? And we're just walking about, and the Victoria Plum was sort of there on the shelf. And I said to her, I said, 'Oh,' I said 'look at that up there, do you like that?' She said 'no, it's bloody horrible.' Right?
Ricky and Steve exclaim in horror
So this is- it's too late, it's too late to go back.
You've spent all your money
It's wrapped, I've- money's spent, it's wrapped, it's under the tree. Alright,
Steve hoots
I'm thinking, 'Oh, I can't believe it.' So I said 'no that-' y'know, made sure she's looking at the right thing- I said 'No, that- that little gnome woman.' - 'Yeah, it's horrible.'
Oh no...
Yeah, Oh. right.
Oh Karl!
Christmas day comes, right.
Yeah
I've opened my stuff.
Ricky laughs
This is really sad
She's about to open hers.
This is like Dickens!
Ricky laughs
Yeah!
She opens hers an' that and she went 'oh, that's- that's lovely, that' I said 'No- uh- don't give me that,' d' y'know what I mean? 'you said you thought it was horrible-'
Karl and Steve crosstalk
You thought she was a liar.
Yeah.
For pretending, for not wanting to hurt your feelings, she was a liar.
And that's.. you know, that's... that's why, y'know-
But things have moved on!
What're you on about? Yeah, but you don't forget, do ya?
You- I don't- I still don't know how this justifies you not buying your girlfriend of 11 years, an actual gift.
Although that was quite touching.
Yeah.
Play a Christmas song, I'm welling up.

metadata.song_track: Let Me Try Again (Laisse Moi le Temps)

transcript.content: Frank Sinatra - Let Me Try Again
Let Me Try Again, by Frank Sinatra. Beautiful song.
Wonderful.
On, er, BBC Radio 2. Well, it's that time of year when we give- give gifts.
Yeah, absolutely and you know-
We like to give, and we like to keep on giving.
Yeah
And that's why it's competition time.
Oh, sure. Nice link.
Yeah

And we have a platinum disc of Madonna's album "Confessions on a Dance Floor" -- it's framed -- classy. Giving that away to.. (laughs) a person who can climb inside Karl's brain, and understand what the hell. he's doing
See, this is the challenge -- I think we can give them a chance. We're also... we've got a.. just because we can this is like one of those gifts we made.
Yeah.
..isn't it? We didn't buy it. We made it. This is
Extras on DVD signed by both of us. Errr..
See, that's like giving a way my camera, in a way. Do you know what I mean? You've got loads of copies of them -- there's no thought in it. You're having to go, do you know what I mean?
But.. (sighs) ohh..
But we were involved with that!
Yeah, we sort of did that --
Well, I did 10 years!
Laughs
If you designed the camera and then built it in a little Factory somewhere and gave it to Suzanne, I'd let you off but you didn't. Also, a copy of "More Flanimals", which I've signed.
Mmh, again?
And um.. some Flanimal collectibles -- now, they're handmade -- you see?

Now, listen! This is.. that's not a cheap gift! That uhh..ahh.. A set of those Flanimals collectibles, right -- they're not toys -- they're handcrafted, right? They went for £600 on eBay. So, that's a good gift.
So if you win them pop them on eBay -- £600!
Or £605 -- you know -- they're very rare.

Yeah, Davey in Belfast, by the way, this is last one. He says, uh "I've bought my wife a silver necklace and I got the shop to put it in a box saying 'white gold', instead of 'silver'. Is this wrong?"
So, if you're Mrs. Davey from Belfast and you get something tomorrow that says 'white gold'.. Um..
Yeah, just.. just maybe be careful. Pop back to the jewelers -- just get them to check it.
He probably thinks he's safe because she's not listening. But any friends..
Yeah
..of David, who's got a wife who's gonna get a silver necklace with 'white gold'...
And she'll be showing that off tomorrow, going: "that's white gold. David got it yesterday." She'll be showing that off on boxing day.
Yeah. I wonder if he'll feel guilty?
Yeah. It'll slowly become.. It'll haunt him like Poe's "The Tell-Tale Heart"; every time he sees it..
Tell the truth. Tell the truth, Davey. Tell the truth. Say it's so.. it's still a beautiful gift. It's a lovely thought, but don't lie.. don't.. Don't mix a lovely gift with a lie.
It's this is this notion that Christmas is a chore: "Oh, I've got the missus something."
I know. I know, I know exactly!
It's bizarre, isn't it?
It should be it should be a joy, Karl.
Yeah, but I do -- I treat are all year-round.
How do you treat your all year round? We know you got through two boxes of condoms but that to me isn't a treat -- waking up next to you every day. (Laughs)

trivia.description: Ricky is referring to a shop known as "St James Ancient Art", which is an antique dealer located in St James, City of Westminster in London, UK.
A "leaving do" is British slang for a leaving party.

A peculiar British Twitter predecessor - British telephone number 88291 is what is known in the UK as a "short message number", which usually charged a fee (Around £2). The users sent via SMS their opinions or answers and were used in the early 00s in the UK for various prize quizzes and audience participation and read off later, and usually used to make a lot of money. Steve refers in another show to these by saying: "Can we rig up some kind of premium rate number?", eyes bulging with imagined riches. These later fell out of favour after they came under increased scrutiny due to fly-by-night companies charging large amounts for these largely pointless services.
Offal refers to the innards of butchered animals that are usually thrown away, used as food for pets, or sold by dodgy butchers at cut rates as sausages. A British euphemism for a penis/genitalia.

Ricky's "More Flanimals", the sequel to his first book "Flanimals" (published 2004) was released in November of the same year, 2005. It depicts unusually-shaped fictional animals, which Karl summarised as being "just a bollock with eyes."

Blockbusters is the name of a real British TV quiz show from the 80s where contestants were given clues and initials, and had to guess the topic, with some hints. Basically, Karl ripped it off for Radio.

The "Gold Run" is a section of the TV gameshow, Blockbusters, that occurs at the end of the game. Contestants have to pick a variety of categories and answer several questions in a row in order to win a prize, but it is timed. The joke here that has been repeated by Ricky and Steve is that, because Karl's clues are so long, the contestants wouldn't have a hope of winning the game because the timer would run out before they could answer.
In the northern dialect of British English, the verb "nick" means to steal something.

Karl is getting nervous here because the show is on the BBC. The BBC has editorial guidelines which compared to commercial channels are quite strict, which include hearing all sides when it comes to "controversial issues" including religion. However, in July of 2005 (the year this was broadcast) the UK suffered a terrorist attack, and tensions were higher at the time than usual, so it is likely Karl was acting out of an abundance of caution due to this incident.

To "do" someone (in the non-sexual way) is when someone has bested someone else at something or cheated them. Also Karl states in "Learn English With Ricky Gervais": "Done you up like a kipper" which has a similar meaning.

In the United Kingdom, administration of the affairs is split between the government in the south and throughout the country in "Councils" which are local administrations. After the post-war period in the 1950s, they started creating low-cost housing, referred to as "Council Housing", which were grouped into areas known as Council Estates. It was not uncommon for various tall tales to come out of these areas, such as stolen items being sold, and various characters doing odd things due to the fact some estates were quite large and had many families living there. Incidentally, both Karl and Ricky grew up on council estates.

Argos is a brick-and-mortar catalogue store in the UK which sells all kinds of items. In the 90s, 00s and in some areas even to this day in 2023, stores provided large colour bound catalogues with all kinds of items in them, and it was/is common among working class people to browse through them to pick out what items they would buy for Christmas, and was a common item people would pick up for friends and relatives if they were going there, as back in the 90s and 00s they were quite heavy due to the large number of pages they had so people wouldn't want to go grab one and walk around with it all day when out shopping.

"Bod" was a 1975 BBC children's cartoon which had a titular character, Bod, which had a round head. Ricky and Steve also make reference to this in the podcast, and Ricky at one point placed an image of Bod on his website so that the international audience the podcast had would understand what they were referring to. Ironically, although Ricky and Steve mock Karl for resembling Bod, the TV show itself was actually made as an expression of Taoist philosophy!
